reason: I'm declining this pull request, as I have ported most of the functionality to the yt-3.0 code base.  This will also make it considerably easier to maintain as well as to implement the varying refinement factors the Chris mentioned.  I will be opening a pull request shortly for yt 3.0.
description:
This is a work-in-progress pull request for Boxlib rewrites.

I have taken the Orion frontend as a starting point and rewritten essentially all of it, although using the original implementation as a guide.  I have implemented Maestro, Castro and Orion detection, although the Maestro/Castro division was only done via finding the fortran parameters.

There are several TODOs:

 * Check that Orion particles are working (I do not have a dataset with particles)
 * Port Nyx (I do not have a recent Nyx dataset, all of mine say 'Castro')
 * Additional cleanups to the code
 * Adding frontend-specific units and fields, which likely exist in the extant frontends
 * Remove the old frontend directories and imports in yt.mods

Note that I am not sure that we should remove the old frontends in advance of the 2.6 release.

I have added a few people as reviewers.  Here is a script that I have run on Orion, Maestro and Castro datasets:

http://paste.yt-project.org/show/3464/

This should, without changing how things are loaded, check that the Boxlib frontend itself is working correctly.  To test "load" and getting the particles correct, you must comment out all of the lines that import any Boxlib frontends (Nyx, Maestro, Castro, Orion) in `yt/mods.py` and then you can run a script like this:

http://paste.yt-project.org/show/3465/

For me, this works, but note that the Maestro detection relies on `probins` existing.  (This can be easily changed.)

I believe that all of the non-Nyx frontends should see performance improvements with this change, both memory and IO-wise.  Nyx will see a memory improvement for large hierarchies.

If I could get some feedback on this, it would be greatly appreciated.  Furthermore, as long as we don't commit and changes to `yt/mods.py` this should be fine to pull from and use.  So I think a good strategy would be initial review and completing the first few steps (including porting Nyx) and then we can iterate on expanding support in the `boxlib` frontend for the specific code types.  Once that has completed, we can remove the old frontend code and standardize here.

UPDATE 1: Addressing Andrew's comments and a few other minor changes.

UPDATE 2: Merging from mainline yt development, although I intend to make this a part of yt 3.0 rather than 2.x.
title: Consolidation of Boxlib frontends

content.raw: One thing I should note is that "inputs", "probin" and "job_info" are now optional.  If they are not provided, those parameters will not be available and the `load` operation will return a BoxlibStaticOutput.  So anything that needs the input file won't be available, but I found that was the vast minority of items used within yt itself.
content.html: One thing I should note is that "inputs", "probin" and "job_info" are now optional. If they are not provided, those parameters will not be available and the load operation will return a BoxlibStaticOutput. So anything that needs the input file won't be available, but I found that was the vast minority of items used within yt itself.

content.raw:
Hi Matthew Turk,

It's pretty simple. I scaled the position data in [this StarParticle file](https://www.dropbox.com/s/0f2bgz7qw1ji6mi/StarParticles) to the domain boundaries of the RadTube dataset you already have. You should be able to put this file at pltXXXXX/StarParticles and read them in normally.

content.raw: @atmyers I had a few questions about your [changes](https://bitbucket.org/atmyers/yt-clean/commits/6718ba4280eb0a5439fc82b7377919b1ec51ef65).  You've added back in the definition of a `read` function -- is that necessary?  And do we need to do something about setting the IO handler class, which you've added but commented out?
content.html: Andrew Myers I had a few questions about your changes. You've added back in the definition of a read function -- is that necessary? And do we need to do something about setting the IO handler class, which you've added but commented out?

content.raw:
Matthew Turk,

The read function gets used in lines 93-95 of io.py. I'm fine with doing this differently if this is bad style, but I thought it made it those lines a bit more readable. 

On the IO Handler, I added that in and and later realized we didn't we don't need it. It will actually get set in the base Hierarachy class as long as long as the data_style is correctly set to orion_native. We should probably just remove the line.
content.html:
Matthew Turk,

The read function gets used in lines 93-95 of io.py. I'm fine with doing this differently if this is bad style, but I thought it made it those lines a bit more readable.

On the IO Handler, I added that in and and later realized we didn't we don't need it. It will actually get set in the base Hierarachy class as long as long as the data_style is correctly set to orion_native. We should probably just remove the line.

content.raw:
Oh, I missed the usage of the read function.  Thanks!

I've received a recent Nyx file (although @caseywstark also told me it's very low priority to do work on yt+Nyx) so I will be able to test with this on it.  So I think what remains, once we perform cleanups:

 * Set up units uniformly as they were before, and then figure out units moving forward
 * Clean up any leftovers in the fields/definitions
 * Test Nyx

One question that came up: should we simply replace the old frontends, and have them import from and override boxlib?  Or should they all be located in the boxlib directory?  Initially I thought we should do the second (which is why it is that way in the code), but I am coming to think we should keep them all in their own directories and import from `yt.frontends.boxlib`.  @atmyers what do you think?
content.html:
Oh, I missed the usage of the read function. Thanks!

I've received a recent Nyx file (although Casey Stark also told me it's very low priority to do work on yt+Nyx) so I will be able to test with this on it. So I think what remains, once we perform cleanups:

  • Set up units uniformly as they were before, and then figure out units moving forward
  • Clean up any leftovers in the fields/definitions
  • Test Nyx

One question that came up: should we simply replace the old frontends, and have them import from and override boxlib? Or should they all be located in the boxlib directory? Initially I thought we should do the second (which is why it is that way in the code), but I am coming to think we should keep them all in their own directories and import from yt.frontends.boxlib. Andrew Myers what do you think?

content.raw: I would say replace and inherit from the boxlib data structures if possible. And it would make the most sense for those to be grouped with the main boxlib frontend. `yt.frontends.boxlib.code` looks right to me.
content.html: I would say replace and inherit from the boxlib data structures if possible. And it would make the most sense for those to be grouped with the main boxlib frontend. yt.frontends.boxlib.code looks right to me.

content.raw: I don't have a strong preference either way, but I think it's probably easier for a hypothetical newcomer interested in adding support for a new Boxlib code if everything is stored in the same directory.
content.html: I don't have a strong preference either way, but I think it's probably easier for a hypothetical newcomer interested in adding support for a new Boxlib code if everything is stored in the same directory.

content.raw:
The following assertion in ```_parse_header_file()``` is causing a failure with one of my Castro datasets:


```
#!python

# We can't vary refinement factors based on dimension, or whatever else 
# they are vaied on.  In one curious thing, I found that some Castro 3D 
# data has only two refinement factors, which I don't know how to       
# understand.                                                           
assert(np.unique(ref_factors).size == 1)     
```

I include the comment because I think there is some confusion here.  The refinement ratio is the jump in resolution between a coarse grid and a fine grid, and it is the same in all dimensions.  In the Header file, there is one value (either 2 or 4 in Castro; just 2 in Maestro, iirc) for each jump between levels.  In Castro, the jump does not have to be the same between all levels.  For instance, my particular problem set has "2 4 4" 

I'm not sure how this plays in with what other codes are doing.
content.html:
The following assertion in _parse_header_file() is causing a failure with one of my Castro datasets:

# We can't vary refinement factors based on dimension, or whatever else 
# they are vaied on.  In one curious thing, I found that some Castro 3D 
# data has only two refinement factors, which I don't know how to       
# understand.                                                           
assert(np.unique(ref_factors).size == 1)

I include the comment because I think there is some confusion here. The refinement ratio is the jump in resolution between a coarse grid and a fine grid, and it is the same in all dimensions. In the Header file, there is one value (either 2 or 4 in Castro; just 2 in Maestro, iirc) for each jump between levels. In Castro, the jump does not have to be the same between all levels. For instance, my particular problem set has "2 4 4"

I'm not sure how this plays in with what other codes are doing.

content.raw: Hi Chris, thanks for testing this.  Adding support for variable-by-level refinement is something I have thought about, but I did not realize any of the codes that we nominally support used that.  Right now, we have a global `refine_by` parameter, and the delta-size between levels is assumed to be `refine_by**delta_level`.  I have to think about where this comes in before changing the behavior, but it seems we need to now.
content.html: Hi Chris, thanks for testing this. Adding support for variable-by-level refinement is something I have thought about, but I did not realize any of the codes that we nominally support used that. Right now, we have a global refine_by parameter, and the delta-size between levels is assumed to be refine_by**delta_level. I have to think about where this comes in before changing the behavior, but it seems we need to now.

content.raw:
In principle I think all of BoxLib supports this, however it is up to the
individual codes whether or not they allow it. I know Maestro currently
only supports a jump of 2.  I also think mine is the only Castro simulation
to really use this feature.

Sounds like it might be more of a headache to worry about implementing than
what it is actually worth, currently.
content.html:
In principle I think all of BoxLib supports this, however it is up to the individual codes whether or not they allow it. I know Maestro currently only supports a jump of 2. I also think mine is the only Castro simulation to really use this feature.

Sounds like it might be more of a headache to worry about implementing than what it is actually worth, currently.

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!
content.html: All tests pass. Good job!
